author: @waddragon
text: thanks for great explanation of the minimum value of the curve is the sample mean. However, the explanation of using absolute is not complete. A better way to explain it is that if we use absolute, we won't be able to tell how well the data is spread from the mean than using the square. The reason is coming from the case A when data has even space from the mean and the case B when some data has very large space from the mean but the rest has small space from the mean. If both case A and B give same result variance value from absolute formula , then we won't be able to tell accurately how well data is spread out . However , by using square, case B will give bigger variance than case A. That's why square is preferred. It is not full proof but i think it provides better intuition than the straight lines instead of parabolic slope 's explanation.

author: @vasily2780
text: I'm having trouble understanding the concept here. Is it to say: "no matter what sample we take, there will generally be a bias towards a smaller variance than the true population variance, thus this is arbitrarily compensated by dividing the estimated variance by a smaller denominator"  The sample variance could be both smaller or larger than the population variance based on how the sample is taken, which would give a certain sample distribution (of many possible SDs). So I don't see the logic of comparing distances between sample points and sample mean vs sample points and population mean. (we can look at variance as a squared "distance" from a selected point such as the sample mean).  Edit: So basically what i'm trying to say is: What is presented in this video simply states that the minimal sum of distances from any sample to a point would be the sample mean which is logical. The question is, what does this have to do with the variance of the sample vs the variance of the population?

author: @samirshukla5959
text: Hey Josh,  Thank you for this wonderful explanation. Based on my learning from this video, I have written an article" https://swapna-samir-shukla.medium.com/what-is-bessels-correction-is-it-really-needed-6f643dc7f84e " In this medium article, I have touched upon basic intuitions of Bessel's Correction followed by mathematical derivations from literature. author: @antonspelecostrostrelec1897
text: Thank you for the video, very interesting.  Here is my R code for playing around :-)  var_custom = function (vect, mean_val) {   return(sum((vect - mean_val) ^ 2) / length(vect)) }  means = c(0, 5, 10, 15, 17.6, 20, 22, 25, 30)  measurements = c(3, 13, 19, 24, 29)  vars = numeric(length(means)) i = 1 for (num in means) {   vars[i] = var_custom(measurements, num)   i = i + 1 }  plot(means, vars, type = "l", col = "blue") abline(v = means[which(vars == min(vars))])  print(paste0("Variance for a sample mean of ", means[which(vars == min(vars))], " is ", var_custom(measurements, means[which(vars == min(vars))]))) print(paste0("Variance for a population mean of 20 is ", var_custom(measurements, 20)))

author: @Google_Censored_Commenter
text: This didn't clear up why we subtract exactly 1 from n though. It just explains why we should subtract some value to begin with, but why 1? if you got 10 million data points, subtracting by 1 doesn't change the sample mean very much. Whereas if you only got 5 data points, it means a great deal. So why not make the value you subtract proportional with n? Like subtracting 10%, or 15%? I understand the more data points you have, the estimated mean is going to become increasingly closer to the population mean, but there's no way subtracting the convenient value of 1 from n is what gets you the closest to the population mean in the majority of cases.

author: @a950721
text: Sorry I am still getting confused. At 5:29, in the inequality, both left hand side and right hand side are using the same n, which is the number of samples.   You argued that the right hand side is greater so that we need to make the left hand side larger by dividing n-1.    However, the right hand side is not the actual population variance. The actual population variance should be using a much larger n to calculate.   What we are doing here is to estimate the population variance but not the right hand side.  Thinking to this point, all the linkage seems broken. How can I relate the right hand side to the population variance?  It is true that the inequality holds. But it does not mean also the population variance is always greater than the left hand side.   Thanks for your videos. They inspire me and teach me a lot.

author: @adlsfreund
text: I'm confused why you keep using the words mean and average interchangeably. I read that the mean, defined like this, is said to reduce the weight of outliers, which seems useful. The distinction between these terms would seem to me especially useful among statisticians.
